A timeframe when Palestinian detainees were held incommunicado and subjected to torture, with reports from the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights indicating systemic abuse across Israeli prison facilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the onset of widespread allegations of torture, abuse, and deaths in Israeli detention facilities, with over 75 Palestinian detainees reportedly dying since October 2023.

keyTakeAways: Mahmoud Abu Foul, a 28-year-old Palestinian from northern Gaza, was tortured in Israeli detention, resulting in permanent blindness and loss of a leg from a prior 2015 bombing.

Abu Foul was detained in late December 2023 and imprisoned at Sde Teiman prison, widely described as a 'prison that breaks men', where he endured beatings and torture including a head strike that caused him to lose his sight.
He was released in October 2025 as part of a U.S.-brokered ceasefire deal that freed nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, many of whom show visible signs of torture and abuse.

Palestinian detainees were held incommunicado without access to lawyers, judges, or families, and were denied medical treatment, including eye drops that were ineffective and not sufficient for treatment.
A growing body of evidence from the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights and medical experts shows systematic torture across all Israeli prison facilities, not limited to Sde Teiman.
The Israeli prison system is described by rights groups as a 'network of torture camps' involving physical abuse, denial of food, medical care, and sexual violence.
At least 75 Palestinian detainees have died in Israeli prisons since October 2023, with medical experts stating many deaths were not natural but due to abuse or execution while restrained.
Israel has returned 100 bodies of Palestinians believed to have died in detention, with some showing signs of torture or execution.
Despite hundreds of abuse reports, only two cases have led to formal indictments, and no prison staff have been charged by Israeli authorities.

Israeli National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir has defended harsh prison policies and has been seen taunting Palestinian political figure Marwan Barghouti, whose son alleges he was beaten in prison.
Marwan Barghouti’s son claims he was beaten during a prison transfer in September 2024, and the family fears for his father’s safety amid reports of abuse.
About 9,000 Palestinian prisoners remain in Israeli custody without trial or proper legal process.
Israel has denied allegations of systematic torture but has not provided evidence to counter the claims, and authorities have not responded to media inquiries.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mahmoud Abu Foul, a 28-year-old Palestinian from northern Gaza, was arrested in late December 2023 at Kamal Adwan Hospital and held in Israeli detention, where he endured severe torture at Sde Teiman prison, resulting in permanent blindness. He was released in October 2025 as part of a U.S.-brokered ceasefire deal that freed nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, many of whom suffered visible injuries and abuse. His case is part of a broader pattern documented by human rights groups, including the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights and B’Tselem, which allege systematic torture, denial of medical care, and incommunicado detention across Israeli prisons. At least 75 detainees have reportedly died since October 2023, with medical experts stating deaths were due to torture or execution. Despite numerous reports, no prison personnel have been charged, and Israeli authorities have not responded to allegations. Key figures like Itamar Ben-Gvir have defended harsh prison policies, while family members of political detainees like Marwan Barghouti express fears of targeted abuse. The article underscores a global human rights concern over the normalization of torture and systemic abuse in Israeli detention facilities.
title: Palestinian detainee relays how torture in Israeli prison made him blind
